trans-unit.source: ATA Capacity Planning
trans-unit.target: ATA Capacity Planning

trans-unit.source: This topic helps you determine how many ATA servers will be needed to monitor your network, including understanding how many ATA Gateways and/or ATA Lightweight Gateways you need and the server capacity for your ATA Center and ATA Gateways.
trans-unit.target: This topic helps you determine how many ATA servers will be needed to monitor your network, including understanding how many ATA Gateways and/or ATA Lightweight Gateways you need and the server capacity for your ATA Center and ATA Gateways.

trans-unit.source: Using the sizing tool
trans-unit.target: Using the sizing tool

trans-unit.source: The recommended and simplest way to determine capacity for your ATA deployment is to use the [ATA Sizing Tool](http://aka.ms/atasizingtool).
trans-unit.target: The recommended and simplest way to determine capacity for your ATA deployment is to use the [ATA Sizing Tool](http://aka.ms/atasizingtool).

trans-unit.source: Run the ATA Sizing Tool and from the Excel file results, use the following fields to determine the ATA capacity you need:
trans-unit.target: Run the ATA Sizing Tool and from the Excel file results, use the following fields to determine the ATA capacity you need:

trans-unit.source: ATA Center CPU and Memory: Match the **Busy Packets/sec** field in the ATA Center table in the results file to the **PACKETS PER SECOND** field in the [ATA Center table](#ata-center-sizing).
trans-unit.target: ATA Center CPU and Memory: Match the **Busy Packets/sec** field in the ATA Center table in the results file to the **PACKETS PER SECOND** field in the [ATA Center table](#ata-center-sizing).

trans-unit.source: ATA Center Storage: Match the **Avg Packets/sec** field in the ATA Center table in the results file to the **PACKETS PER SECOND** field in the [ATA Center table](#ata-center-sizing).
trans-unit.target: ATA Center Storage: Match the **Avg Packets/sec** field in the ATA Center table in the results file to the **PACKETS PER SECOND** field in the [ATA Center table](#ata-center-sizing).

trans-unit.source: ATA Gateway: Match the **Busy Packets/sec** field in the ATA Gateway table in the results file to the **PACKETS PER SECOND** field in the [ATA Gateway table](#ata-gateway-sizing) or the [ATA Lightweight Gateway table](#ata-lightweight-gateway-sizing), depending on the [gateway type you choose](#choosing-the-right-gateway-type-for-your-deployment).
trans-unit.target: ATA Gateway: Match the **Busy Packets/sec** field in the ATA Gateway table in the results file to the **PACKETS PER SECOND** field in the [ATA Gateway table](#ata-gateway-sizing) or the [ATA Lightweight Gateway table](#ata-lightweight-gateway-sizing), depending on the [gateway type you choose](#choosing-the-right-gateway-type-for-your-deployment).

trans-unit.source: If for some reason you cannot use the ATA Sizing Tool, you need to manually gather the packet/sec counter information from all your Domain Controllers for a period of 24 hours with a very low collection interval (approximately 5 seconds).
trans-unit.target: If for some reason you cannot use the ATA Sizing Tool, you need to manually gather the packet/sec counter information from all your Domain Controllers for a period of 24 hours with a very low collection interval (approximately 5 seconds).

trans-unit.source: Then, for each Domain Controller, you must calculate the daily average and the busiest period (15 minutes) average.
trans-unit.target: Then, for each Domain Controller, you must calculate the daily average and the busiest period (15 minutes) average.

trans-unit.source: The ATA Center can handle an aggregated maximum of 400,000 frames per second (FPS) from all the monitored domain controllers.
trans-unit.target: The ATA Center can handle an aggregated maximum of 400,000 frames per second (FPS) from all the monitored domain controllers.

trans-unit.source: The amounts of storage dictated here are net values, you should always account for future growth and to make sure that the disk the database resides on has at least 20% of free space.
trans-unit.target: The amounts of storage dictated here are net values, you should always account for future growth and to make sure that the disk the database resides on has at least 20% of free space.

trans-unit.source: If your free space reaches a minimum of either 20% or 100 GB, the oldest collection of data will be deleted.
trans-unit.target: If your free space reaches a minimum of either 20% or 100 GB, the oldest collection of data will be deleted.

trans-unit.source: This will continue to occur until 5% or 50 GB of free space remains at which point data collection will stop working.
trans-unit.target: This will continue to occur until 5% or 50 GB of free space remains at which point data collection will stop working.

trans-unit.source: The storage latency for read and write activities should be below 10 ms.
trans-unit.target: The storage latency for read and write activities should be below 10 ms.

trans-unit.source: The ratio between read and write activities is approximately 1:3 below 100,000 packets-per-second and 1:6 above 100,000 packets-per-second.
trans-unit.target: The ratio between read and write activities is approximately 1:3 below 100,000 packets-per-second and 1:6 above 100,000 packets-per-second.

trans-unit.source: When running as a virtual machine dynamic memory or any other memory ballooning feature is not supported.
trans-unit.target: When running as a virtual machine dynamic memory or any other memory ballooning feature is not supported.

trans-unit.source: For optimal performance, set the **Power Option** of the ATA Center to **High Performance**.
trans-unit.target: For optimal performance, set the **Power Option** of the ATA Center to **High Performance**.

trans-unit.source: When working on a physical server, the ATA database necessitates that you **disable** Non-uniform memory access (NUMA) in the BIOS.
trans-unit.target: When working on a physical server, the ATA database necessitates that you **disable** Non-uniform memory access (NUMA) in the BIOS.

trans-unit.source: Your system may refer to NUMA as Node Interleaving, in which case you will have to **enable** Node Interleaving in order to disable NUMA.
trans-unit.target: Your system may refer to NUMA as Node Interleaving, in which case you will have to **enable** Node Interleaving in order to disable NUMA.

trans-unit.source: See your BIOS documentation for more information.
trans-unit.target: See your BIOS documentation for more information.

trans-unit.source: Note that this is not relevant when the ATA Center is running on a virtual server.
trans-unit.target: Note that this is not relevant when the ATA Center is running on a virtual server.

trans-unit.source: Active Directory forests and domains
trans-unit.target: Active Directory forests and domains

trans-unit.source: ATA can monitor traffic from multiple domains from a single Active Directory forest.
trans-unit.target: ATA can monitor traffic from multiple domains from a single Active Directory forest.

trans-unit.source: Monitoring multiple Active Directory forests requires separate ATA deployments.
trans-unit.target: Monitoring multiple Active Directory forests requires separate ATA deployments.

trans-unit.source: A single ATA deployment should not be configured to monitor network traffic of domain controllers from different forests.
trans-unit.target: A single ATA deployment should not be configured to monitor network traffic of domain controllers from different forests.

trans-unit.source: There are various tools that you can use to discover the average packets per second of your domain controllers.
trans-unit.target: There are various tools that you can use to discover the average packets per second of your domain controllers.

trans-unit.source: If you do not have any tools that track this counter, you can use Performance Monitor to gather the required information.
trans-unit.target: If you do not have any tools that track this counter, you can use Performance Monitor to gather the required information.

trans-unit.source: To determine packets per second, perform the following on each domain controller:
trans-unit.target: To determine packets per second, perform the following on each domain controller:

trans-unit.source: Open Performance Monitor.
trans-unit.target: Open Performance Monitor.

trans-unit.source: Performance monitor image
trans-unit.target: Performance monitor image

trans-unit.source: Expand **Data Collector Sets**.
trans-unit.target: Expand **Data Collector Sets**.

trans-unit.source: Data collector sets image
trans-unit.target: Data collector sets image

trans-unit.source: Right click **User Defined** and select **New** > **Data Collector Set**.
trans-unit.target: Right click **User Defined** and select **New** > **Data Collector Set**.

trans-unit.source: New data collector set image
trans-unit.target: New data collector set image

trans-unit.source: Enter a name for the collector set and select **Create Manually (Advanced)**.
trans-unit.target: Enter a name for the collector set and select **Create Manually (Advanced)**.

trans-unit.source: Under **What type of data do you want to include?**, select **Create data logs and Performance counter**.
trans-unit.target: Under **What type of data do you want to include?**, select **Create data logs and Performance counter**.

trans-unit.source: Type of data for new data collector set image
trans-unit.target: Type of data for new data collector set image

trans-unit.source: Under **Which performance counters would you like to log** click **Add**.
trans-unit.target: Under **Which performance counters would you like to log** click **Add**.

trans-unit.source: Expand **Network Adapter** and select **Packets/sec** and select the proper instance.
trans-unit.target: Expand **Network Adapter** and select **Packets/sec** and select the proper instance.

trans-unit.source: If you are not sure, you can select **<All instances>** and click **Add** and **OK**.
trans-unit.target: If you are not sure, you can select **<All instances>** and click **Add** and **OK**.

trans-unit.source: To do this, in a command line, run `ipconfig /all` to see the name of the adapter and configuration.
trans-unit.target: To do this, in a command line, run `ipconfig /all` to see the name of the adapter and configuration.

trans-unit.source: Add performance counters image
trans-unit.target: Add performance counters image

trans-unit.source: Change the **Sample interval** to **1 second**.
trans-unit.target: Change the **Sample interval** to **1 second**.

trans-unit.source: Set the location where you want the data to be saved.
trans-unit.target: Set the location where you want the data to be saved.

trans-unit.source: Under **Create the data collector set** select **Start this data collector set now** and click **Finish**.
trans-unit.target: Under **Create the data collector set** select **Start this data collector set now** and click **Finish**.

trans-unit.source: You should now see the data collector set you just created with a green triangle indicating that it is working.
trans-unit.target: You should now see the data collector set you just created with a green triangle indicating that it is working.

trans-unit.source: After 24 hours, stop the data collector set, by right clicking the data collector set and selecting **Stop**.
trans-unit.target: After 24 hours, stop the data collector set, by right clicking the data collector set and selecting **Stop**.

trans-unit.target: Stop data collector set image

trans-unit.target: In File Explorer, browse to the folder where the .blg file was saved and double click it to open it in Performance Monitor.
